columns.text: In this exercise, we will define a dealer market and differentiate it from an auction market. In addition, we'll explainÂ the meaning of OTC and the name of the large OTC stock market.  We'll also define the largest auction market in the United States.

a) A **dealer market** is a place where multiple dealers advertise the prices at which they will buy or sell certain securities or instruments. When trading on the dealer market, a dealer (also known as a "market maker") electronically displays the prices at which it is ready to establish a market in a security, hence providing liquidity and transparency.

**Difference**  between dealer market and an auction market - a physical place is required for an auction market.  Also, in a dealer market, the dealer handles the majority of the purchasing and selling. The fundamental goal of an auction market, on the other hand, is to connect buyers and sellers.

b) **OTC** (over-the-counter) refers to the days when stocks were purchased and sold at counters in offices around the country. In the United States, auction markets are the most common method of trading major company shares. Today, a large portion of the stock market is conducted electronically, rather than at a central location.

c) The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is the largest market of its kind and facilitates the trading of more than 85% of all different kinds of shares. The American Stock Exchange (AMEX) and several regional markets, such as the Pacific Stock Exchange, are also examples of other types of auction exchanges.
